title: Sum of Angles of a Triangle
description: The sum of the interior angles of a triangle equals 180° (π radians). One of the most fundamental results in Euclidean geometry.

overview.historicalContext: This theorem is one of the oldest in mathematics. Euclid proved it around 300 BCE (Elements, Book I, Proposition 32). The theorem characterizes Euclidean geometry.
overview.problemStatement:
**Triangle Angle Sum**:

For any triangle with vertices p₁, p₂, p₃:
$$\angle p_1 p_2 p_3 + \angle p_2 p_3 p_1 + \angle p_3 p_1 p_2 = \pi$$
overview.proofStrategy: Euclid's proof constructs a line through one vertex parallel to the opposite side. The modern proof uses Mathlib's Euclidean geometry library.
keyInsights: In spherical geometry the sum exceeds π
In hyperbolic geometry the sum is less than π
This distinguishes Euclidean from non-Euclidean geometry

conclusion.summary: The triangle angle sum theorem is verified, characterizing flat Euclidean geometry.
